metadata.title: Medial Collateral Ligament Sprain  Conservative Management
synonyms: tibial ligament knee sprain conservative management
ligament sprain, medial collateral: conservative management
tibial collateral ligament sprain: conservative management
ligament sprain, tibial collateral: conservative management
anatomical location body part affected: Knee; medial collateral (tibial) ligament of knee joint
description: The primary functions of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) are to maintain tibiofemoral joint alignment and to restrain valgus and external rotation forces to the knee. It has a complex and layered anatomy with multiple insertions and functions(1,7)
Patients with an MCL sprain may experience a minor trauma, tearing the superficial layer, or a high-energy  valgus torque on the knee joint, affecting the superficial and deep layers(7)
The MCL is the most commonly injured/torn ligament of the knee, particularly in athletes. It has been reported to be torn in 7.9% of all knee injuries(1,2,5,7)
Incidence of MCL sprains is reported to be 0.24 per 1,000 per year and twice as high in males(1,5)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Localized tenderness and soft tissue swelling at MCL
Pain with weight-bearing  (WB) on involved leg, causing altered gait mechanics
Guarding, muscle spasm, and joint effusion in severe cases
Patients with recent MCL sprain often present wearing knee brace and using assistive ambulatory device  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Suspect complications in cases with unremitting gross knee effusion. Multiple noncontractile structures of the knee might be damaged in severe MCL sprains(1,11) –Medial capsule tear –Medial meniscus—rule out meniscal injury prior to active rehabilitation –Anterior/posterior cruciate ligament (ACL/PCL)—assess stability before return to prior activities –Tibial plateau fracture

causes: MCL sprain usually is caused by excessive valgus torque from a direct blow or indirect force to the lateral knee while thefoot is fixed(1)

Contact sports: authors of a large descriptive epidemiological study of intramural and intercollegiate athletes in the UnitedStates found that MCL injuries were relatively common in contact sports(11)
pathogenesis: Tears can be microscopic, gross partial, or complete

Grading of the severity of tears. Valgus or abduction stress test is performed at 0 degrees and 30 degrees flexion. If laxityoccurs at 30 degrees and not at 0 degrees MCL injury usually is present, without injury to the PCL or posterior capsule(1,9)–Mild—grade I: no evidence of valgus instability with firm end-feel,  valgus stress can elicit pain. Microscopic tears of thesuperficial, deep, or both layers–Moderate—grade II: mild to moderate valgus instability in knee flexion, pain with valgus stress. Partial tear of the MCL–Severe—grade III: valgus instability (gapping) in both knee flexion and extension and tibial external rotation. Completetear of the MCL
Return to play: when athletes with MCL sprain can safely resume practices or competition after conservative managementalso varies from case to case(9)
risk factors: Participation in contact sports (such as soccer, football, wrestling, hockey, judo, and rugby)(9)
Wearing a knee brace might increase risk in the unbraced knee, particularly in backs and kickers. However, it is unclearwhether prophylactic knee braces prevent or increase MCL injuries(1,9)
Evidence is lacking on whether the playing surface (i.e., natural or artificial) affects the risk of MCL sprain

overall contraindications precautions: Educate patient on weight-bearing  restrictions and correct use of knee brace; confirm rehabilitation protocol and contraindications/precautions with physician
Once the diagnosis confirms valgus stress instability, further MCL stress testing should be postponed until the discharge

contraindications precautions: Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically
Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage
Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures
other: Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions ›Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic ›Stretching and resistive exercises, which put stress on the MCL, should not be performed during the acute stage of healing ›Cryotherapy  contraindications(3)
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old
Persons with aversion to cold ›Whirlpool contraindications(3)
Post-op  surgical incision with dehiscence (i.e., bleeding surgical wound), sutures, or staples
Skin ulcers caused by venous insufficiency, edema, or lymphedema
Skin conditions such as atopic eczema, ichthyosis, and senile pruritus (i.e., itching)
Tissue flaps or recent skin grafts

Acute inflammation ›Electrotherapy  contraindications (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician, electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(3)
Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs)
Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman
Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease
With patients with compromised mental ability
With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat)
Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: MCL sprain/pain, instability, and functional loss in ADLs, occupation, and sport
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Medial meniscal tear(1) Anterior cruciate ligament tear(1) Epiphyseal/tibial plateau fracture(1) Medial compartment osteoarthritis(1) Pes anserine bursitis(1) Medial tibial plateau fracture(1) Vastus medialis obliquus injury(1) Medial plica band syndrome(1) Patellar dislocation with spontaneous reduction(1) Bone bruise(1) Referred pain (e.g., from hip, as hip pathology is the leading significant cause of pain in the knee among children)(1) Patellofemoral pathology(1) Osteochondral injury(1)
prognosis: Generally, good to excellent for most patients with grade I or II sprains. It is possible for athletes to return to sport as early as 1-4 weeks from injury. Athletes with grade III MCL injury treated without surgery may return as early as 5 to 7 weeks from injury.(9)Typically, individuals with grade II and III injuries return to activity between 8 and 12 weeks(1)

Patients with grade III MCL tear with concomitant injuries, medial meniscus tear, and/or ACL tear may be treated surgically. Most surgeons elect not to repair an isolated grade III MCL injury.(1) If the MCL tears distally near its tibial attachment, surgeons may recommend repair(9)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Back to physician as indicated; aquatic exercise therapist
treatment summary: In the acute stage (~weeks 1–3):  treatment generally consists of pain and edema management, gait training with appropriate assistive device as indicated, passive and active-assisted  ROM, patella mobilization, and isometric exercises for the quadriceps, hamstrings and adductors

In the subacute stage (~weeks 3–8):  treatment typically continues previous exercises and pain management, as well as begins closed-chain  strengthening and flexibility exercises, endurance, and proprioception/balance training. Toward the end of this phase a walk/jog program or stationary cycling might commence, as well as advanced strengthening exercises, such as isokinetic training, as appropriate

Return to activity phase: functional training with specific exercises, drills, and return-to-work  or play criteria (e.g., function at pre-injury  level, able to perform full work-  or sport-related  activities) tailored for the patient. Criteria may include pain-free,  full ROM and 90% quadriceps and hamstring strength compared to contralateral leg(9) –A Swain test of rotary instability may be performed with knee flexed to 90 degrees flexion with tibia fully externally rotated. If patient has medial knee joint pain,he or she may not be ready for return to play(9) –Criteria for advancement and return to sport are more important than time since injury alone. Kim et al. criteria to return to sport include no symptoms with sprinting or with sport-specific  multidirectional movements and plyometrics. Patient must achieve established physical performance levels for his or her sport and position of play(9)

An investigator conducted a case study to compare real-time  visual feedback during a 6-inchbox  drop jump on knee valgus compared to standard knee rehabilitation alone in a 14-year-old  female high-school  soccer player with acute medial knee pain and medial joint instability. After 4 sessions of visual feedback training to improve her movement patterns during the drop jumps, her reported medial knee pain decreased from 6/10 to 0/10,with decreased knee valgus(6) . maintenance or prevention: Address causative factors to prevent valgus stress and recurrence of MCL injury such as orthotics for overpronation, continued strengthening of hip abducters and external rotators,core strength, and body mechanics for the patient’s sport(9)
“Nordic hamstring lowers” (player starts in kneeling position with partner holding onto ankles; player slowly falls forward toward the floor using hamstrings to control fall for as long as possible)

Prophylactic braces have been recommended because reinjury is not uncommon in contact sports. However, whether bracing prevents MCL sprain remains questionable. Negative effects of bracing include reduced performance, leg cramping, and fatigue(1,9)
